Title: Affiliate Associate Professor
Thrust/Department/Division: Thrust of Bioscience and Biomedical Engineering
Overview: Angela Ruohao Wu is an associate professor in the Division of Life Science and the Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering at The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology. Angela obtained her B.S. in Bioengineering from the University of California, Berkeley, her M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in Bioengineering from Stanford University, and her post-doctoral work also at Stanford University. In 2015, Angela co-founded Agenovir Corporation, a CRISPR-based therapeutics company targeting infectious diseases for a complete cure. Her research group is passionate about the development of new microfluidics and genomics technologies at the interface of basic biology and engineering, and using these interdisciplinary approaches to investigate biological mechanisms and human diseases. As recognition of her achievements in technology and innovation, Angela was named one of MIT Technology Review Innovators under 35 Asia in 2016, and a World Economic Forum Young Scientist in 2018.
Research Interest: ['Genomics', 'Cancer genomics', 'Systems biology', 'Microfluidics and nanofluidics', 'Single particle / molecule / cell studies']

Title: Affiliate Associate Professor
Thrust/Department/Division: Thrust of Urban Governance and Design
Overview: Dr. Pengyu Zhu is an Associate Professor in the Division of Public Policy at Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (HKUST). He is the Co-Director of the Master of Public Policy Program at HKUST. Prior to joining HKUST, Dr. Zhu has been a faculty member in the Department of Community and Regional Planning at Boise State University, USA (2011-2016) and in the Department of Geography at University of Hong Kong (2017-2019). Dr. Zhu received his Ph.D. in Policy, Planning and Development from the Sol Price School of Public Policy at University of Southern California in 2011. He has taught courses on transportation and land use, transportation economics, economics applications to planning and policy, urban economics, urban geography, quantitative research methods, and urban design and site planning studios. Dr. Zhu’s research focuses on the Transportation--Land Use--Economic Development Policy nexus, including: 1) Travel Behavior (including automobile, transit, non-motorized transportation modes, and telecommuting), Location Choice, and Associated Implications for Economic and Environmental Issues; 2) Links between Transportation Infrastructure, Housing Market, and Economic Development (e.g. residential segregation, mobility, accessibility and labor market success; transportation finance; and the economic impact of transportation infrastructure); 3) Using Spatio-temporal Big Data Analytics to Inform Urban Planning and Policy Decisions. To date, his work has been published in major academic journals such as Landscape and Urban Planning, Urban Studies, Annals of Regional Sciences, Transportation, Transportation Research Part D, Urban Geography, Cities, Regional Science and Urban Economics, and International Journal of Environmental Science and Technology. Moreover, his instrumental work has been highlighted in an array of major scientific media such as Wall Street Journal, Slate Magazine, CityLab, Per Square Mile, and Reason Foundation. In January and February 2017, Dr. Zhu was ranked the top 5% and 3% of researchers on Academia.edu by 30-day views of his research articles. In the past few years, Dr. Zhu have received over USD $200,000 (equivalent) in research grants. Due to his exceptional work in the field of Regional Science, Dr. Zhu was awarded the 25th Charles M. Tiebout Prize in Regional Science in 2011 and the Regional Science Springer Prize in 2014.
Research Interest: ['Big data and urban planning ', 'Sustainable transportation ', 'Economic development policy ', 'Housing and land use policy ', 'Migration and employment']

Title: Affiliate Assistant Professor
Thrust/Department/Division: Thrust of Urban Governance and Design
Overview: Wen WANG is an Assistant Professor in the Division of Social Science at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology. She received her Ph.D. in Economics from Duke University, and her research interests include environmental economics, urban economics, and public economics. Prof WANG's research tries to develop and apply economic methods to analyse and evaluate environmental policies. The majority of her work focuses on understanding the distributional impacts and welfare impacts of environmental policies, especially across residents of different tenure status (renters vs. owners) and races. She is particularly interested in property market responses and re-optimization of residential housing decisions corresponding to policies and shocks, and measures welfare changes taking account of residential sorting and housing market re-equilibration.
Research Interest: ['Environmental Economics', 'Urban Economics', 'Public Economics', 'Industry Organization']

Title: Affiliate Assistant Professor
Thrust/Department/Division: Thrust of Sustainable Energy and Environment
Overview: Dr. Changying Xiang received his Bachelor of Architecture degree and Master of Architecture degree from the Harbin Institute of Technology (HIT), he received his second master degree (MSc in Technology in Architecture) in sustainable architecture direction from Aalborg University. From 2018 autumn to 2022 Spring, he worked in the Light & Colour Centre in the Department of Architecture and Technology at the Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU) for three and a half years and received the Ph.D. degree in Architecture. During the research period in Norway, Dr. Xiang worked closely with SINTEF (the Norwegian Foundation for Industrial and Technical Research),  The Research Center for Sustainable Solar Cell Technology (SuSolTech), and IFE (Institute for Energy Technology) to develop advanced coloured photovoltaics prototypes and architectural design methodologies for BIPV applications. He was also a member of NTNU Energy Team Solar, and a member of New Bauhaus @ NTNU. Dr. Xiang is now an Assistant Professor in the ISD division of HKUST, an affiliated Assistant Professor at the Thrust of Sustainable Energy and Environment of HKUST GZ. He has the ambition to promote the development of smart carbon-neutral buildings and cities with holistic design strategies and cutting-edge technologies.  His research interests include designing smart integrated PV systems for building and urban context, prefabrication construction, sustainable architecture and urban design, light and colour in architecture and cities, resilient carbon-neutral cities and climate responsive design etc. He is a Member of the National Standardization Technical Committee of Solar Photovoltaic Energy System (BIPV Thematic group), a professional member of the International Solar Energy Society, a member of the International Colour Association (AIC Study Group on Environmental Colour Design), a member of the Daylight Award Community, a member of the China Fashion Color Association-Architectural and Environmental Color Committee, a member of Active House Academic Committee of Architectural Society of China (ASC AHAC). He has worked as a schematic architect at the Architectural Design & Research Institute of Tsinghua University, Co. Ltd, Beijing and he co-founded an architectural design and construction company conducting prefabricated low-energy housing in Denmark. As an architect with an entrepreneurial spirit, Dr. Xiang is enthusiastic about promoting the sustainable revolution of the AEC industry and actively collaborates with the PV industries. In his vision, the future world will be powered by renewable energy systems and can provide more climate-resilient, culturally diverse, ecologically friendly, and human-centered environments. Everyone can and should contribute to the sustainability of our beautiful and magical planet.
Research Interest: ['Sustainable architectural design', 'Building integrated photovoltaics systems', 'Carbon-neutral cities', 'Light and colour in architecture and cities', 'Prefabricated construction', 'Climate responsive design']

Title: Affiliate Assistant Professor
Thrust/Department/Division: Thrust of Urban Governance and Design
Overview: Han Zhang is Assistant Professor in the Division of Social Science. He obtained his PhD in Sociology from Princeton University, and his B.S., Computer Science and B.A., History from Peking University. His research spans computational social science, social movements, and quantitative methods. His recent works have advanced methods of building large-scale protest event dataset for China based on deep learning algorithms using text and image as data, and have utilized the dataset to examine the landscape, causes, and consequences of social protests in China. His past research has been published in Sociology Methodology, and has won the Mayer N. Zald Distinguished Contribution to Scholarship Student Paper Award from the Section on Collective Behavior and Social Movements of the American Sociological Association.
Research Interest: ['Collective action and social movements ', 'Social network analysis ', 'Computational social science ', 'Machine learning']

Title: Adjunct Professor
Thrust/Department/Division: Thrust of Sustainable Energy and Environment
Overview: RAFIQUL GANI, PhD, is currently an adjunct professor at KAIST (South Korea) and a visiting professor at Texas A&M University. For 34 years, starting from 1985, Prof Gani worked at the Department of Chemical & Biochemical Engineering, Technical University of Denmark, and is the former head and co-founder of CAPEC. Prof Gani served as an editor-in-chief of Computers and Chemical Engineering journal (2009-2015) and currently serves as editor for the Sustainable Production & Consumption journal. He is also a member of the editorial advisory boards of several international journals, including Computers and Chemical Engineering and Current Opinion in Chemical Engineering. Prof Gani has been awarded Doctor Honoris Causa degrees from University Politehnica Bucharest, University of Pannonia, Babes-Bolyai University & University of Maribor. Prof Gani is the ex-president of the EFCE (2015-2018), a member of the Danish Academy of Science, a Fellow of the AIChE and a Fellow of IChemE. He received the AIChE Computers in Chemical Engineering award in 2015, the EFCE Jacques Villermaux Medal in 2019, the AIChE Sustainability Engineering Forum award in 2020, the winner of the IChemE Sargent Medal in 2021 and the Thomas and Donna Edgar CACHE Award for Excellence in Computing in Chemical Engineering Education given by American Society of Engineering Education (announced in June 2022). In 2018, Prof Gani co-founded the PSE for SPEED Company, that develops, implements and employs state of the art PSE methods and tools to solve a wide range of problems of industrial and research significance, reliably, efficiently and very rapidly. He has published 550 articles in peer reviewed international journals and proceedings plus 5 edited books and 1 text-book. His publications have given him a H-index of 73 in GoogleScholar, 62 in SCOPUS and 54 in Web of Science (January, 2022). Prof Gani’s current research interests continue with the development and application of computer aided methods and tools for modelling; property estimation; process-product synthesis, design & intensification; and process-product-tools integration with emphasis on energy, sustainability and application of a systems approach
Research Interest: ['Multiscale modelling for managing the complexity in process-product design', 'Sustainable process  design and analysis, including process intensification', 'Computer aided product (molecule and mixture)  design', 'Development of systematic computer aided methods & tools', 'Development of predictive models for prediction of properties of chemical systems']

Title: Adjunct Professor
Thrust/Department/Division: Thrust of Bioscience and Biomedical Engineering
Overview: Professor Joseph Kwan is a seasoned administrator, educator and researcher. He completed his BA in Bacteriology and MPH in Occupational Hygiene from the University of California at Berkeley; MS in Clinical Microbiology from the University of California at San Francisco; and a Doctorate in Environmental Science and Engineering from the University of California at Los Angeles. Prior to his current roles at HKUST GZ, He was a long serving staff at HKUST (Clear Water Bay) which he joined in 1991 as the founding director of Health, Safety and Environment; and Adjunct Professor in the Division of Environment and Sustainability, as well as in the Department of Ocean Science.  In addition to his administrative duties, he teaches courses in environment and health; supervises post-graduate students on dissertation research; and teams up with colleagues in conducting multi-disciplinary research studies on the transport and fate of infectious bioaerosols in the indoor environment. Together with his research partners, they innovated various hazards control technologies to combat infectious disease outbreaks, including SARS and COVID-19. Prior to his assignment in Hong Kong, he worked for many years in the Hazards Control profession in the USA.  He served in leadership roles at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Rockwell International, and Northrop Aircraft Company. He was a Research Clinical Microbiologist at the University of California at San Francisco before joining the Hazards Control field. In addition to his assignments at HKUST and HKUST GZ, he is very active in serving our community in various volunteer roles, including government advisory committees and Non-Government Organizations in the Health Care, Education and Social Service sectors.
Research Interest: ['The transport and fate of infectious microbes in the indoor environment', 'Novel hazards control technologies', 'Optimization of health care service delivery efficiency through engagement of new technologies']

Overview: Prof. Lu Tao WENG received his Ph.D. degree from the Catholic University of Louvain in Belgium. He is currently the Director of the Materials Characterization and Preparation Facility and an Adjunct Professor of the Advanced Materials thrust at HKUST(GZ). He is also an Adjunct Professor of the Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering at HKUST. As an internationally acknowledged surface scientist, he has often been invited to deliver keynote lectures at international and domestic conferences. He is currently a member of the International Conference Organizing Committee on Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometry (SIMS) and the only representative in Greater China. To expand the international influence of China's research in SIMS, he organized a special issue "SIMS Research in China" in an international journal "Surface and Interface Analysis in 2020. He has published three book chapters, six review papers and more than 130 peer-reviewed articles.

Overview: Prof. ZHANG Zhong obtained his B.Sc., M.Sc., and Ph.D. Degrees in Solid Mechanics in 1990, 1996, 1999 from University of Science and Technology of China. He has also been an exchange student at Institute of Material Research II, Karlsruhe Research Center, Germany from Jun 1997 to Jul 1998, and the Engineering Division, Rutherford Appleton Laboratory, UK from Aug 1998 to Dec 1998. Prof. ZHANG has been awarded Bayer AG Young Scientist Award from Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2008, Sofja Kovalevskaja Award for Young Scientist from Alexander von Humboldt Foundation of Germany, Excellence Award of Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2011, and Excellence Award of Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2011. He is now a Professor & Director at Chinese Academy of Sciences Key Laboratory of Nanosystem and Hierarchical Fabrication, National Center for Nanoscience and Technology, China. He is also acting the Chinese Editor of Composites Part A: Applied Science and Manufacturing since 2016, and one of the editorial board members of academic journals such as Composites Science & Technology, J Compos Mater, Tribology Int, J Multifunctional Composites academic journals etc.

Title: Adjunct Associate Professor
Thrust/Department/Division: Thrust of Computational Media and Arts
Overview: Liang Tan is professor of digital media arts at Guangzhou Academy of Fine Arts, doctoral supervisor, PhD in Design HKPolyU, and director of institute of Digital Art Technology. He received his PhD in interaction design from School of Design at the Hong Kong Polytechnic University and MFA in digital media design from GAFA respectively. He has 20 years’ experience in teaching, research and practice in digital art. He conducted his research as a visiting scholar at Art School of Aix-en-Provence in France 2009-2010. He has obtained a range of research grants, and published a series of academic books and articles, including “Processing Interactive Programming Art” the first coding art book in China. The practice projects include new media installation designs in China Hall of 2005 Japan world EXPO and 2010 Shanghai world EXPO. His current research interests include embodied interaction design, digital media art, and metaverse art. He is also adjunct associate professor of Computational Media and Arts at HKUST(GZ), and visiting professor of Southern University of Science and Technology.

Title: Adjunct Associate Professor
Overview: Prof. Wei Xu received his Ph.D. from the University of California, Irvine in 2006.  He received his M.S. and B.S. from Tianjin University.  From 2006 to 2010, he worked at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill as a Postdoc and Research Associate.  His research work was focusing on the microfabrication of devices for interdisciplinary applications, including microfluidic chips and single-cell analysis microchips.  From 2011 to 2021, he joined the biggest university core lab, the Core Lab of King Abdullah University of Science and Technology University in Saudi Arabia, as a Scientist and Lead, where he developed core lab management, user service, and vendor management skills.  Afterward, in 2021, he joined HKUST(GZ) as Nanofabrication Facility Associate Director.  He is co-author of over 25 publications/conference articles and listed as co-inventor on 8 patents.

Title: Professor of Practice
Overview: Prof. Bai received his Ph.D. degree from Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 2011, M.S. degree from the Singapore-MIT Alliance program at National University of Singapore in 2003, and B.S. degree from Xi’an Jiaotong University in 2002. During his Ph.D. research, he studied tensile-strained Ge for electronic and optoelectronic applications, demonstrated high quality Ge epitaxial thin film with 1.3% tensile strain, world’s highest record at the time. From 2002 to 2003, he worked at Institute of Materials Research and Engineering in Singapore on novel polymeric MEMS sensors with high biocompatibility for protein detection and high throughput diagnosis. He was a senior associate engineer at Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corporation (SMIC) in Shanghai from 2003 to 2004 and established key PECVD dielectric deposition process for SMIC’s 90nm IC technology.In 2011, Prof. Bai co-founded the School of Nano-Science and Nano-Engineering (Suzhou) of Xi'an Jiaotong University, where he served as assistant dean and later deputy dean until 2021. During the time he also co-established the Center for Micro and Nano Manufacturing of the Collaborative Innovation Center of Suzhou Nano Science and Technology under the national “2011” program, and served as deputy director. In 2022, he joined HKUST(GZ) as professor of practice at the Center for Technology Leadership and the Microelectronics Thrust. He currently also serves as committee member of the CMES Micro & Nano Manufacturing Technology Branch. He served on the organizing committees and technical program committees of international conferences, and serves as technical expert for national and provincial level R&D grants.
Research Interest: ['Semiconductor thin films and devices ', 'MEMS', 'Micro-devices for bio-sensing']

Title: Professor of Practice
Overview: Man Chan received his B.Eng degree from the University of Hong Kong in Mechanical Engineering in 1993, and Ph.D. degree in Control and Systems Engineering from Toin University of Yokohama, Japan, in 1999. Prior to joining the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (GZ), he held a position in ASM Pacific Technology Ltd (ASMPT Group) (0522.HK) as Director of Manufacturing Technology.  Dr Chan joined ASMPT group in 2004, he started working in ASM Technology Singapore (ATS) and was mainly responsible for the development of ultrasonic transducers and wire bonding process studies. From 2008, he was appointed to assist in the establishment ASM Technology China (ATC) which is the 1st R&D center of ASMPT in Mainland China as technical manager. After the establishment of ATC, from 2010, he started worked in ASM Manufacturing Services (AMS) and has a lot of chances to travel between China and Hong Kong. With these opportunities and experiences, Dr Chan established the Manufacturing R&D (MRD) department in ASMPT, including engineers from both Hong Kong (ATHK) R&D Center and China plant. The main job of MRD department is to develop future manufacturing technologies and deliver these technologies to ASMPT various product teams starting from design to high volume manufacturing (HVM) and then to quality control as a whole bunch of engineering solutions. Technologies includes mechanical design, manufacturing processes, molding design, technology-based budget and quality control. During his PhD studies in Japan, Dr Chan published 8 full papers, 5 international, 35 local symposium papers (in Japanese), received the Awaya Award from the Acoustical Society of Japan in 2000,Student Paper Award in Japan Research Institute of Material Technology in 1998, and published 4 patents during work. Dr Chan’s research interest includes precision engineering for semiconductor equipment, high performance advanced plastic materials, 3D printing technologies and the development of technology in carbon fiber composites from design to high volume manufacturing and quality control.
Research Interest: ['Carbon Fiber Related Materials and Structural Design', 'Mechatronics System Design', 'Ultrasonic Vibration System Design', 'Manufacturing Technology Research and Development (Plastics 3D printing, Metal 3D printing)']

Title: Professor of Practice
Thrust/Department/Division: Thrust of Computational Media and Arts
Overview: Haijie HU (胡海杰) is an interdisciplinary leading designer, a pioneer, a thinker and a practitioner in the field of multi-dimensional space experience, and the co-founder of space experience firm VAVE STUDIO. In 2007, after graduating in interior architecture at the University of Rhein-Main, Germany, Haijie Hu held the roles of creative director at the pioneering architectural firm 3deluxe and the brand communication firm Atelier Markgraph. In 2013, Haijie Hu and Tobias Geisler co-founded the space experience firm VAVE Studio in Frankfurt, Germany, integrating their respective practices in the field of spatial perception and content narrative into a more focused research direction "spatial experience design", combining spatial narrative The dimensions of practice are in the areas of interaction and experience. In 2015, Haijie Hu returned to Shanghai, China and established VAVE Shanghai, leading the Chinese team and applying the practice of VAVE Studio to commercial and cultural projects in China. In 2022, VAVE Shenzhen was established. Facing the changes of the times, emerging cities, emerging industries and emerging lifestyles have demand for narrative and experience, focusing more on the integration of physical space and digital experience, using mixed fields as containers for content, allowing multidimensional experiences to serve the narrative.
Research Interest: ['1）Narrative Space Design', '2）Hybrid Field', '3）Shy-tech']

Title: Professor of Practice
Thrust/Department/Division: Thrust of Bioscience and Biomedical Engineering
Overview: Dr. Li Xiao Yi, Benjamin holds a PhD in Pharmacology from the University of Illinois at Chicago and is a life member of its Alumni Association. During 1991 and 1992, he was a postdoctoral fellow for R&D in cardiovascular drugs with Parke-Davis Research Division of Warner-Lambert Company, a major pharmaceutical company in the United States. He focused mainly on the pharmaceutical R&D, innovative drugs in particular, such as preclinical development, research in pharmacy and pharmacology and analysis of pharmaceutical products etc. In recent years, Dr. Li is engaged in developing anti-tumor drugs with new targets and different mechanisms and the combination therapies in oncology. After obtaining the PhD Pharmacology, Dr. Li returned to Hong Kong and established “Lee’s Pharmaceutical (HK) Limited” and “Zhaoke Pharmaceutical (Hefei) Company Limited” in 1994. Since then, he has been responsible for and concentrated his time and professional efforts throughout from startup to the listed fully integrated pharmaceutical company with global perspectives. Now, the Group is fully integrated with solid infrastructures in drug development, clinical development, regulatory, manufacturing and sales and marketing based in Mainland China with headquarters in HK.

Title: Professor of Practice
Overview: Professor Quanke Su is currently the Chief Engineer of the Institute for Cross-sea Engineering and Integrated Transportation, Professor of Practice in Intelligent Transportation at System Hub at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (Guangzhou). He also serves as the Vice Chairman of the Bridge Branch of the China Civil Engineering Society, and a member of the 13th National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC).Professor Su graduated from the School of Highway, Chang'an University in 1987 with a master's degree in Bridge and Tunnel Engineering, and later joined the Guangdong Institute of Transport Research during which he participated in the design and research work and construction practice of many major projects. He was the Deputy Director of Guangdong Highway Engineering Quality Supervision Station and the Chief Engineer of Guangdong Institute of Transport Science.Professor Su has over 30 years of practical experience in the field of transport infrastructure. Prior to the construction of the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge (HZMB), he was selected by the governments of Guangdong, Hong Kong and Macao to be the Chief Engineer of the world-class cross-harbor project, the HZMB, which lasted for over 18 years from 2004 to 2022.Professor Su has made long term exploration in promoting technological integration and collaborative innovation among Guangdong, Hong Kong and Macao, and is the project leader of the Key Program supported by the National Eleventh Five-Year Plan Science and Technology Grant, and the 14th Five-Year Plan National Key Program for Research and Development. His main research areas include strategic planning and technical architecture for major engineering projects, structural and durability technologies for marine engineering, digitalization and intelligent construction, intelligent operation and maintenance technologies for transport infrastructure, as well as integrated transport and autonomous transport systems.In terms of part-time social positions, Professor Su serves as a member of the National Expert Group on Medium and Long-term Science and Technology Development Planning for 2035, the Sichuan-Tibet Railway Joint Technology Tackling Expert Group, the Expert Group on Integrated Development of Transport and Energy, the Expert Committee of the Ministry of Transport, the Provincial-Ministry Joint Technical Expert Group for the Shenzhen-Zhongshan Passage and the Dalian Bay Cross-Sea Passage, and the Deputy Director of the Expert Committee of the Guangdong Provincial Highway Society.Professor Su was awarded the 2017 National Science and Technology Innovation People (also known as "Bridge Titan", total 10 awardees nationwide, jointly selected by eight institutions including the Chinese Academy of Sciences, the Chinese Academy of Engineering, the Ministry of Science and Technology, and the Ministry of Education). He also received the Outstanding Contribution Award (2 awardees worldwide) from the International Association for Bridge Maintenance and Safety (IABMAS) in 2018, the Guangdong Provincial Science and Technology Progress Special Award (ranked No. 1) and the South Guangdong Model in 2019, the Government Special Allowance Expert issued by the State Council in 2020, the South Guangdong Innovation Award and the 6th National Outstanding Professional and Technical Talent in 2021. Among all the science and technology awards and honors, the National Outstanding Professional and Technical Talents Award releases every five years, recognizing his outstanding contribution in the construction of the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge.
Research Interest: ['•\tFuture Cross-sea Engineering', '•\tBridge and Tunneling Engineering', '•\tIntelligent Transportation', '•\tInfrastructure Digitalization']

Overview: Dr. Weitao Che is an Assistant Professor of Practice in Urban Governance and Design Thrust at The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (Guangzhou) (HKUST(GZ)). He received his PhD in GeoInformation Science from The Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK) in 2014, and served as a Research Associate at Institute of Space and Earth Information Science of CUHK. He has been an Associate Researcher of Shenzhen Institute of Advanced Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences (SIAT). He has also interned at the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (UNESCAP). Currently, he is also a committee member of the Virtual Geographic Environment Professional Committee of the Chinese National Committee of the International Society for Digital Earth (CNISDE) and an expert for the City Information Modeling (CIM) Think Tank. His research interest includes 3D GIS and virtual geographic environments, CIM and digital twins, as well as mobile sensing.
